titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Oversize Ms. Codex 826: Liber de astronomia

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Oversize Ms. Codex 826: Liber de astronomia are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. See the Creative Commons Public Domain Mark page for usage details, http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/mark/1.0/.

notesStmt.note: Title from title page (front flyleaf recto).
Incipit: Scientia species habet quarum melior post scientiam fidei.
Explicit: ... i[n] duo media s[ed] q[uod] e[st] i[n] figura prima.
Contemporary and near-contemporary marginal notes in several hands throughout.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: 7 of the usual 9 books of this astronomical work (Zacour-Hirsch Catalogue) translated by Gherardo da Cremona.

author.persName: Jābir ibn Aflah, Abū Muhammad, 12th cent

supportDesc.extent: 64 leaves : 261 x 198 (193 x 128) mm. bound to 270 x 203 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Parchment, ii + 64 + i; [1-64]; modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 50 long lines; frame-ruled in lead.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in a Gothic script by several hands.

decoDesc.decoNote: Decorated initial in red and blue (f. 1r); decorative ascenders and descenders added by a later hand beginning at the end of Book 5 (f. 31v), some with red ink (f. 33v-34r); trigonometric and spherical trigonometric diagrams throughout, most commonly in the margins; occasionally the text is shaped to accommodate a larger diagram (for example, f. 23v).

origin.p: Probably written in France, but possibly written in Spain, ca. 1300 (Zacour-Hirsch Catalogue) or ca. 1250-1300 (Thomas R. Adams).

history.provenance: Formerly owned by Don A. Canovas del Castillo (bookplate, inside upper cover).
Formerly owned by Wilfred M. Voynich, 1920 (Thomas R. Adams).
